document.text: your being hurt, , hesaid.  I am doing tolerably well here. I get 25 dols. a month, with victuals and clothings, have a comfortable home for Mandy the folks here call her Mrs. Anderson, the children .. . go to school. We are kindly treated. Now, if you will write and say what wages you will give me, I will be better able to decide whether it would be to my advantage to move back again. . . . We have concluded to test your sincerity by asking you to send us our wages for the time we served you, the doubleedged letter continues. I served you faithfully for 32 years and Mandy 20 years. At 25 dols. a month for me, and 2 dols. a week for Mandy, our earnings would amount to 11,680 dols. Add to this the interest for the time our wages has been kept back, and deduct what you paid for our clothing. . . Please send the money by Adams Express, in care of V. Winters, Esq., Dayton, Ohio.

She had told Adams her husband, one bullet penetrating the that she would have no more to do with him. This so enraged him that he is said to have sworn vengeance on his rival. At the close of the exercises, as Rush ing came out of the schoolhouse door, youtig Adams walked up behind him and without a word of warning shot Rushing in the back. Rushing fell off the porch, and Adams shot him twice after he had fallen, inflicting fatal wounds. Adams then shot Greeley Jones, the teacher of the district, inflicting a slight wound in the shoulder.

It is hard to believe with an the things she did that she was still considered inferior to a man. She never went to school a day in her life but her father, Who was a minister, taught her to read and she went through the parsonage library and on to her Grandfather Quincys larger . one. When her husband went off Ug the first Continent! Congress in Philadlphia, she supervised his law business, ran the farm and did all the work as housewife and mother that most women had to do in those days. document.text: Woman Sandbags Woman. Milwaukee, Wis. Special. Mrs. F. F. Adams, Jr, wife of the vice-president of the F. F. Adams Tobacco Company reported to the police that she had been sandbagged and robbed of 18,500 while on a train comin to this city from Chicago. She stated that she had gone ! to Chicago Monday to draw a 25,000 ! inheritance from the First National Bank of that city. After paying some debts she started back on an evening  train with 16,000 in cash and a cer tificate of deposit for 2500. On the way she went into the toilet room of the car, where another woman entered and struck her over the back of the head with a billy or some other blunt instrument. She was knocked uncon scious and robbed.

document.text: With only 10 letterm an returning Willu m Campbell will have a host of freshman and sophomOres i n the starting lineup when tne Seminole District football season opens Sept. 6 and new head coach Ronnie Cox figures they will need some time to mature. Our young players have to come around to plug the gaps, both offensively and defen sively, Cox says, Right now we are concentrating on our first game. We are not even considering the second game of the season. We need time to grow and we will have to play one gameat a time Cox is fortunate that the Genrals do not open when all the other teams in the district see action Friday night. William Campbell has an open date for the first week of the season, which will allow them another week of preparation before they meet Appomattox in its season opener. Cox is returning to the helm of the Generals after an absence of five years. The 10 year coaching veteran led the Generals to two district crowns beofre leaving for a coaching post in Alabama. His most recent coaching duties saw him as an assistant if they are to be successful in a quest for a Seminole District title. Cox will probably have the Generals in a split T offense with either Allen Harper of Kip Burch at quarterback and -William Mitchell and Alvin Younger at running back, i Other candidates for the running back post are Mike M arstin, Ronnie Chambers, Cornelius Adam? Buddy Gar rett and Andy Carr. Ricky Davis or Charles White will man the wingback position while George Smith, Boo Younger and Tony  Herndon are all fighting fore starting assignments at end. ! Paul Ginther and Wayne Claybrook are battling for the  center slot and six players are  waging a battle for the tackle l positons. Seniors Danny Fallin and Sam Baker seem to have the  jnside track, but they are being  pushed hard by Varney Riddle, a junior, and sophomores Glenn Epperson, Ricky Trent and  MattMosby. Mike Coates and Benny Nash are trying to nail down guard posts, but Jimmy Adams, Jim Nichol and Bill Hodges are j making their presence felt. At least five or six of the offensive starters will also see duty on the defensive unit. Cox says, we dont have the depth or the size we would like to have, but we have 40 players on  the junior varsity squad. I don believe in rebuilding years, just want to put my best football players on the field

document.text: With 87 ip attendance, a highly successful conference of Region VI of Junior Chambers of Commerce was held on Tuesday evening at the Appomattox Elementary School. The attendance record was Alta vista 11, Amherst 2, Appomattox 16, Bedford 9, Chatham 3, Danville 3, Farmville 5, Halifax 5, Lynch burg 22, South Boston 6. The at tendance also included Jack Barnes, Past President Va. Jaycees Mack Abernathy, Vice President of Region I Cecil Vaughan, Vice Pres ident Region II Bill Matze, Vice President, Region VI Rhae Adams, Leadership Training Chairman Bruce Reynolds, Orientation Chair man, State of Va. A1 Newman, In ternational Director Earl Camp bell, National Director Va. Jaysees. Bill Matze presided at the con ference. A report was made by each chapter as to projects underway, both civic and money-making, gains or losses in membership, and plans for the future. A report was given as to progress being made on the state office building scheduled for construction in Lynchburg in the near future. A1 Newman urgently requested 100 membership in Junior Chamber International.

Qlynns 8peech Historic Utteranoo. The convention opened with a kejr- aote speech which Ufta Temporary Chairman Glynn into the ranks of the foremost orators of the country. It had everything to make It a historic utterance. In thought It fitted into the needs of the hour It presented the Issues as they are now before the American people. The Republican platform cslttdem of the presidents foreign policy fur nished the speaker a text, although the numerous cases with which he Illus trated his line of thought showed extended research. He defended the presidents coarse In the maintenance of neutrality by an overwhelming ar ray of facts and precedents. He called as witnesses all of the prominent Re publican officials and all the great presidents he showed how, from Washington down, the nations most illustrious executives have dealt as President WMson lias with violations of our nations rights. He showed how nearly all of the great nations of Europe have at times Interfered with our shipping, attacked eur war vessels, killed oar officials and Invaded our country and how, Instead of set tling our grievances by war, we had settled them by negotiation, Just aS the president of the United States IS trying to do today. pikes Q. O. P. Dun. He piled up precedent upon prec edent end cited the course pursued by president after president. The con cluding phrase, just as the president ef the United States Is doing today, appealed to the audience with Increas ing force and It le sure to become one of the popular phrases of the cann palm. He has spiked one of the Mg guns of the enemy. When his speech has been read throughout the country, aS It will be, the Democratic speakers will have aU the authority they need for the silencing of Republican criti cism. To make a Republican orator ridiculous It will only be necessary to draw ex-Governor Glynns speech upon him and ask him how Grant settled the Virginias case when a Spanish commandant shot the captain, thirty- six of the crew and sixteen of the pas sengers  how Harrison settled the Bal timore case when a Junior officer waS killed and sixteen sailors wounded lu the streets of Valparaiso how Lincoln settled the burning of SL Albans how1 the Alabama claims were settled how Van Boren settled the Carolina case how John Adams treated the 2,800 vio lations of the neutrality law by France how Washington dealt with the 400 cases where France and Eng land seized our ships. In all these cases, the answer Is that the presidents then ln office did not go to war they settled them by negotiations, jiust as the president of the United States la trying to do to day. Covers All Important Issues. While tlie chief merit of Governor Glynns speech lies in the unanswer able argument advanced ln support of the presidents position on neutrality, It covered all Important Issues in volved ln this campaign. It enumerat ed the remedial measures enacted dur ing the past three years, Including tariff legislation, antitrust legislation, and currency reform, and it did not omit preparedness. It Is a compen dium of Information and argument and will ln Itself supply sufficient ma terial for campaign speakers through out the country. It began with Ameri canism and ended ln a eulogy of the president All ln all. It was an epoch- making speech and satisfied the audi ence as convention audiences are sel dom satisfied. It measured up to the highest requirements of the occasion It captivated the convention. It was as perfect from the stand point of rhetoric as It was complete from the standpoint of argument The arrangement was artistic the sen tences were all well balanced the pe riods were rounded. There was a rhythm ln the words that pleased the ear. The thoughts were well dressed not gaudily or shabbily but appro priately. document.text: William O. Durrett, one of the best- known young farmers of Albemarle County, shot and killed Guy Adams, a tenant on his farm, Blrdwood, near Ivy Depot. Cattle belonging to Adams got In  cornfield on the Blrdwood farm, and upon the tenants refusal to drive them off. a dispute followed In which Adams attacked Durrett with a hoe, knocking him from his horse. Durrett fired hta pistol, the ballet en tering Adams head, and death ensued within three hours. Durrett pde ttt the city and surrendered to the author- ties Adams, who was thirty yean old, leaves a wife and several children.

H ie bridegroom wore his late fathers block wool tuxedo, which featured cutaway tails with satin striped pants and faille lapels. Miss Andrea Lucas of Richmond and Miss Anna Dickerson of Prospect, cousins of the bride, were flower girls. They wore identical pink floor length gowns and carried baskets of pink mum petals. Master Matthew Guido of Sportsylvania, cousin of the bride was ring bearer. He wore a three piece heather grey and cream pin-striped suit. Mrs. John A. Lucas of Richmond, aunt of the bride, was m istress of ceremonies. Miss Beverly Goin of Appomattox and Miss Lisa Goin of P rospect, cousins of the bride, attended the guest register. For her daughters wedding, Mrs. Adams chose a royal blue and pink pin-striped crepe dress with burgundy accessories with a corsage of pink mums. document.text: While a number of men were blasting in a rock cut hear Tarry Sound, Ont., a heavy charge of dynamite prematurely exploded. Two of the men, Bmltfi aud Hlilman, wore instantly killed. John Olson was fatally in jured,-While others of the -gang were ser iously hurt. ----- A great amount of rain has fallen in Colorado the past three days, caus ing heavy floods In various localities. The principal damage has been railroad wash outs, which have been quickly repaired, and trains are runntng regularly-on al lines. ___ - Twelve hundred miners have struck at Corn ing. RendvlUe and Hemlock, O , in conse quence of resolutions adopted in the miners convention Across the line in Kansas City, Kan , an unknown thief entered the branch of the American National Bank dur ing the momentary absence of the cashier, and prying open a desk, secured 1,000 In currency or more, and made his escape. ____ 8. D. Moser, president of the Morgan county, W. Va , court, was shot near Taw Paw by some unknown assailant. J . C. Williams, a visitor to Hot Springs, Ark , from Montana, stabbed himself in the bre ,sf four times with a knife. Fulling to end his life in that manner, he jumped lieqij first into a doep well and broke his neck. ----- A skiff in which were three men were cap sized in the Ohio River, at Pittsburg, by the waves of a passing steamer, and two of tho men drowned. Their names were Wm. I iekman and Thos. Shaughnessy. ----- In the United States Circuit Court in SanFrancIsoo lirwin T. Earl has been granted an injunc tion against Philip D. Armour and Robert Graham, who Earl alleges had used an in- fiii g m e D t of his patent ventilator for fruit cars. The injunction will tie up all Armours cars and force the use of Earls cars. ---- At Alen own, ten miles south of Winchester, Ky , a boiler in the harvest field of Dr. Sid Allen exploded, killing four boysDallas I ggard, aged twelve Travis Haggard, fourteen Willie Berryman, seventeen, and Alexander Turpin, fourteen. ---- United States troops, under Lieutenant Bullock Lad an encounter with Yacqul Ind.ans ten miles south of Tucson, Arizona, killingthree of the band and capturing tho test Three solders were wounded. document.text: which we were thinking a week ago is beginning to grow dim. so that not long after thatand right on up to nowthere are descendants of the first man who look so cruel and are so wicked that any one in liis right mind would say, If thats the image of God, I dont want any part of it. Adam was cut off in other words not only from God but from himself, his best self. Further, he was cut off from his wife. The story of Genesis tells of the joyful words of welcome when Adam sees Eve for the first time. Paradise, for both of them, is complete only when the other one, the loved one, is there to share it. Now all is changed. Adams only w o r d about his wife isThe woman Thou gavest me, she gave me the fruit . .. Its all Gods fault for sending Eve, or its all Eves fault for tempting him, it couldnt be his own fault, oh no! When you get to the point where you wont take responsi- bibty for your own acts, when you blame everyone but your self for your sins and y o u r troubles, then you have really broken off relations with th e human race. The Solemn Question The first question God asks of man rings like a solemn want ing bell in the heart of every one some time or other. Where are you? You are here now, at this moment but you a r e wherever you act, you a r e wherever things happen  oi fail to happen  because of you. Someone perhaps m i g h t have believed in God if it had not been for you. You are there in that persons despairing cyni cal mind. Where are you? Re sults of what you say, what you do never stop with the saying and doing. Like stones thrown into a pond they create ripples that spread to distant shores. If an old man could realize all the evil that he caused during his lifetime, the burden of it would be overpowering. Yet there is another and a happier side. Gods question, Where are you? reminds us that God does care what we do. He does not easily give up, He seeks men in their dark hiding places. If He de mands obedience and punishes suffering, and He does, it is a sign of hope for it shows that God takes human lives serious ly He is not content to let men go. document.text: ,-What are the goals for the Junior Chapter of the FHA The Jr. Chapter of the Future Homemakers of America pre sented two skits to emphasize their goals for 1976-77 at their monthly meeting, Oct. 22nd. Sharon Taylor, Jr. Chapter president presided. Jayne Doss, 2nd Vice President presented the skits. The first skit was on the goal Improving Personality traits. Chapter members in this skit were Karen Johnson, Marilyn Ran dolph, Debbie Hamlet, Judy Martin, Margaret Moore, Cyn thia Goode  Vicki Moser. The 2nd skit was on the goal Learning to Understand and Get Along With Others. In this skit were Jayne Doss,Cheryl Walton, Gina Adams, Sue Price, and Judy Jamerson. The topic for the years program is Its A Big World - Get Ready. . The programs for the year are October 22, Skits on goals. November 18, Mrs. Waltons Christmas Program, December 16, Mrs. Carter, Mrs. Whately Ways of Getting Along With Others. January 20, Puppet Show - Improving Personality Traits. document.text: We have only about 150 bushels left, and while they last we will b t glad to fill your orders at the very low price of  2.50 per bushel, two bushels to the sack, F, O. B. Lynchburg. Adams Bros.Paynes Co.
